F–A !Scorers !Attendance |- bgcolor="#ddffdd" |14 July 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[Czarni Jasło]] |A |4-0 |? |? |- bgcolor="#ddffdd" |28 July 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[Pogoń Lwów]] |A |3-0 |? |? |- bgcolor="#ddffdd" |11 August 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[KS Cracovia (football)|KS Cracovia II]] |A |4-0 |? |? |- bgcolor="#ffdddd" |23 August 1918 |{{Flag icon|Weimar Republic}} [[SFC Opava|DSV Troppau]] |A |1-10 |? |? |- bgcolor="#ddffdd" |8 September 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[Pogoń Lwów]] |A |3-0 |? |? |- bgcolor="#ffdddd" |22 September 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[KS Cracovia (football)|KS Cracovia]] |A |2-3 |[[Henryk Reyman]] (2) |? |- bgcolor="#ddffdd" |10 November 1918 |{{Flag icon|POL}} [[KS Cracovia (football)|KS Cracovia]] |A |1-0 |[[Jacek Stopa]] |? |} ==Notable players== * {{Flag icon|POL}} [[Stanisław Ziemiański]] * {{Flag icon|POL}} [[Henryk Reyman]] ==External links== *[http://historiawisly.pl/wiki/index.php?title=Sezon_1918_%28pi%C5%82ka_no%C5%BCna%29 1918 Wisła Kraków season at historiawisly.pl] {{Wisła Kraków seasons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1918 Wisla Krakow season}} [[Category:Wisła Kraków seasons]] [[Category:Association football clubs 1918 season]] [[Category:1918 in Polish football|Wisla]] {{Poland-stub}}

{{Year in Monaco|1999}}
The following lists events that happened during '''[[1999]] in [[Monaco]]'''.
==Incumbents== *[[List of rulers of Monaco|Monarch]]: [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Rainier III]] *[[Minister of State (Monaco)|State Minister]]: [[Michel Lévêque]]
==Events==
===January to June===
*January 23 - [[Caroline, Princess of Hanover|Princess Caroline of Monaco]] married [[Prince Ernst August of Hanover (born 1954)|Ernst August, Prince of Hanover]] in a civil ceremony at the Palace.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hubbard|first1=Kim|title=Ernst Goes to Monaco|url=http://people.com/archive/cover-story-ernst-goes-to-monaco-vol-51-no-5/|website=People|publisher=Time Warner|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref> It was also the 42nd birthday of the princess bride. *March 2 - [[AS Monaco]] made it to the fourth qualifying round of the [[1999-2000 UEFA Cup]]. They lost to [[RCD Mallorca]], 4-1. *March 9 - [[AS Monaco]] played a second match against [[RCD Mallorca]], this time on their home turf at [[Stade Louis II]] in [[Fontvieille, Monaco|Fontvieille]], and won, 1-0. *May 16 - [[Michael Schumacher]] won the [[1999 Monaco Grand Prix]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibson|first1=Sean|title=25 reasons why Michael Schumacher is the great F1 driver of all time|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/formula-1/2016/08/25/25-reasons-why-michael-schumacher-is-the-greatest-f1-driver-of-a/|website=The Telegraph (UK)|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref>
===July to December===
*July 20 - A daughter, Alexandra, was born to the Prince and Princess of Hanover.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ein Mädchen für Caroline|url=https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.abendblatt.de/archiv/1999/article204691705/Ein-Maedchen-fuer-Caroline.html|website=Hamburger Abendblatt|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref> Prince Ernst was photographed by [[paparazzi]] urinating outside the hospital in [[Vöcklabruck]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frost|first1=Caroline|title=Ernst von Hannover: The Prince and the Pee|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/801735.stm|website=The BBC|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{Europe topic|1999 in}}
[[Category:1999 in Monaco| ]] [[Category:Years of the 20th century in Monaco]] [[Category:1990s in Monaco]] [[Category:1999 by country|Monaco]] [[Category:1999 in Europe|Monaco]] [[Category:Monaco stubs]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Use South African English|date=March 2017}} {{third-party|date=August 2014}} [[Image:Abahlali baseMjondolo Logo.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Abahlali baseMjondolo logo]] '''Abahlali baseMjondolo''' ({{IPA-zu|aɓaˈɬali ɓasɛm̩dʒɔˈndɔːlo|[[Zulu language|Zulu]]:}}, ''Shack Dwellers''), also known as '''AbM''' or the '''red shirts''',<ref>[http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/comment/40854 Anatomy of a hunger strike]. Pambazuka.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref name="UKZN">Richard Pithouse, ''‘Our Struggle is Thought, on the Ground, Running'. The University of Abahlali baseMjondolo'', [[UKZN]], 2006</ref> is a shack-dwellers' movement in South Africa well known{{dubious|date=March 2018}} for its campaigning against evictions<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/04/nelson-mandela-south-africa-anc After Nelson Mandela, what next for South Africa?], by Sean Jacobs, ''The Guardian'', 4 July 2013</ref> and for public housing.<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2011-01-07-2011-may-be-the-year-that-civil-society-rises-as-an-opposition-force 2011 may be the year that civil society rises as an opposition force], Mandy Rossouw, ''Mail & Guardian'', 7 Jan 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21564829-it-has-made-progress-becoming-full-democracy-1994-failure-leadership-means Over the rainbow], ''The Economist'', 20 October 2012</ref> The movement grew out of a road blockade<ref>[http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=2453595 Article in the Sunday Tribune newspaper by Fred Kockott describing the road blockade] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019024008/http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=2453595 |date=19 October 2007 }}</ref> organised from the [[Kennedy Road, Durban|Kennedy Road]] shack settlement in the city of [[Durban]] in early 2005<ref>[http://www.monthlyreview.org/0206pithouse.htm] Struggle is a School by Richard Pithouse, [[Monthly Review]], 2006</ref><ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/files/RREPORT_VOL106_BRYANT.pdf] 'Delivery and Dignity' by Jacob Byrant, Journal of Asian & African Studies, 2007</ref> and now also operates in the cities of [[Pietermaritzburg]]<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/5012313/ANC-to-shift-to-the-Left-after-South-Africas-presidential-election.html] 'ANC to shift to the Left after South Africa's presidential election', ''The Telegraph'', London</ref> and in [[Cape Town]].<ref>[http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=797246]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Article in the Sowetan newspaper on the launch of the Cape Town branch of Abahlali baseMjondolo</ref><ref name="Post-Apartheid South Africa 2011">Social Movement Media in Post-Apartheid South Africa, by Wendy Willems,''Encyclopaedia of Social Movement Media'' (Ed. John D. H. Downing, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, 2011)</ref><ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201110281069.html Cape Town Administration Violates the Rights of the Poor], Carmen Ludwig, All Africa, 27 October 2011</ref> It is the largest [[shack]] dweller's organisation in South Africa<ref>[http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=124&art_id=qw1135493101629B225]'South Africa's Poor Have Had Enough' Carol Landry, Agence France-Presse, December 2005</ref><ref name="guardian.co.uk">[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/dec/30/zuma-failing-black-south-africans] Jonathan Steele, ''Why 2010 Could Be An Own Goal for the Rainbow Nation'', [[The Guardian]], 30 December 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.capetownmagazine.com/whats-the-deal-with/Whats-the-Deal-With-Toyitoyi/125_22_17384 What's the Deal with the Toyi-Toyi], by Lisa Nevitt,''Cape Town Magazine'', November 2010</ref> and campaigns to improve the living conditions of poor people<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=MVc7sRyf4wcC&pg=PA140 'The State of Resistance: Popular struggles in the Global South'] edited by Francois Polet pp.139–140, McMillian 2007</ref> and to democratise society from below.<ref>[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/12/27/18556529.php] iPolitiki ePhilayo</ref>
The movement historically refused [[party politics]], and has [[boycott]]ed elections<ref>[http://libcom.org/library/abahlali-basemjondolo-%E2%80%98-homemade-politics%E2%80%99itics Matt Birkinshaw Abahlali baseMjondolo: A homemade politics, 2009]. Libcom.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.sabcnews.com/portal/site/SABCNews/menuitem.5c4f8fe7ee929f602ea12ea1674daeb9/?vgnextoid=55d6a6fd9d795210VgnVCM10000077d4ea9bRCRD&vgnextfmt=default 'Shack dwellers honour their leader'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604020639/http://www.sabcnews.com/portal/site/SABCNews/menuitem.5c4f8fe7ee929f602ea12ea1674daeb9/?vgnextoid=55d6a6fd9d795210VgnVCM10000077d4ea9bRCRD&vgnextfmt=default |date=4 June 2011 }} by SABC News, 16 December 2009</ref> and has a history of conflict with both the [[African National Congress]] and the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]].<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=133565 The seed of a new opposition?] ''Business Day'', 7 February 2011</ref> (Despite this, it announced its support for the Democratic Alliance in the [[South African general election, 2014|2014 elections]].<ref name="dailynews_02052014">[http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/da-signs-pact-with-kzn-landless-people-1.1682799#.U2PKr3V52Dc DA signs pact with KZN landless people] SAPA, ''The Daily News'', 2 May 2014</ref><ref name="ecn_02052014">[https://archive.is/20140502165718/http://www.ecr.co.za/post/abahlali-throws-support-behind-da/ Abahlali throws support behind DA] Thrishni Subramoney and SAPA, ''East Coast Radio'', 2 May 2014</ref>) Its key demand is that the social value of urban land should take priority over its commercial value<ref>[http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2010/03/448244.html Abahlali baseMjondolo March on Jacob Zuma, Durban, South Africa], 22 March 2010, UK IndyMedia</ref> and it campaigns for the public expropriation of large privately owned landholdings.<ref name="ReferenceC">[Street Traders: A Bridge Between Trade Unions and Social Movements in Contemporary South Africa], by Ercument Celik, Nomos, Freiburg, 2009</ref> The key organising strategy is to try "to recreate [[The commons|Commons]]" from below by trying to create a series of linked [[commune (intentional community)|commune]]s.<ref>Joel Kovel, 'The Enemy of Nature', 2007 Zed Books, New York, p. 251</ref>
According to ''[[The Times]]'', the movement "has shaken the political landscape of South Africa."<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article734635.ece 'Stench of shanties puts ANC on wrong side of new divide'] by Jonathan Clayton 25 February 2006</ref> According to Professor Peter Vale, Abahlali baseMjondolo is "along with the [[Treatment Action Campaign]] the most effective grouping in South African civil society."<ref>Peter Vale – [http://www.dispatch.co.za/article.aspx?id=393176 Insight into history of SA an imperative] 2010/04/09 Daily Dispatch. Dispatch.co.za {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206140452/http://www.dispatch.co.za/article.aspx?id=393176 |date=6 February 2012 }}</ref> Khadija Patel has written that the movement "is at the forefront of a new wave of mass political mobilisation".<ref name="dailymaverick.co.za">[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-09-16-shack-dwellers-take-the-fight-to-ethekwini-and-the-anc-takes-note/ Shack dwellers take the fight to eThekwini – and the ANC takes note], Khadija Patel, ''The Daily Maverick'', 16 September 2013</ref> However the movement has faced sustained, and at times violent, repression.<ref name="dailymaverick.co.za"/><ref name="sabarometerblog.wordpress.com">[http://sabarometerblog.wordpress.com/archive/volume-eight-2010/political-tolerance-on-the-wane-in-south-africa/ Political tolerance on the wane in South Africa], Imraan Buccus, ''SA Reconciliation Barometer'', September 2010</ref><ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201307250942.html?viewall=1 On the Quality of Electioneering in South Africa], Frank Meintjies, ''All Africa'', 25 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.sacsis.org.za/site/article/1789 Lessons from the Demise of Thabo Mbeki], Jane Duncan, ''SACSIS'', 16 September 2013</ref>
== Context == [[Image:Image Foreman Assembly.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Abahlali Assembly, Foreman Road Settlement]]
In 2001, the [[eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality|eThekwini]] Municipality, which governs Durban and [[Pinetown]], embarked on a '[[slum clearance]] programme' that meant the steady demolition of shack settlements and a refusal to provide basic services (e.g. electricity, sanitation etc.) to existing settlements on the grounds that all shack settlements were now 'temporary'. In these demolitions some shack dwellers were simply being left homeless and others subjected to unlawful forced evictions to the rural periphery of the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219072803/http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |archivedate=19 December 2008 }} 'Business As Usual', Centre on Housing Rights & Evictions (Geneva), 2008</ref><ref>[http://lib.ohchr.org/HRBodies/UPR/Documents/Session1/ZA/COHRE_ZAF_UPR_S1_2008_CentreonHousingRightsandEvictions_uprsubmission.pdf] COHRE report to the United Nations, 2008</ref> In early 2008, the United Nations expressed serious concern about the treatment of shack dwellers in Durban.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/7session/reports.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315175004/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/7session/reports.htm |archivedate=15 March 2008 }} United Nations Statement on Housing Rights Violations in South Africa</ref> In the run up to 2010 there was also concern about the possibility of [[eviction]]s linked to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] across South Africa<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/12/south-africa-world-cup-2010] ''The Guardian'' World Cup 2010: football brings defining moment for South Africa, 12 June 2009</ref><ref name="sundayherald.com">[http://www.sundayherald.com/international/shinternational/display.var.2524562.0.0.php The real winners and losers: of the beautiful game] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810233106/http://www.sundayherald.com/international/shinternational/display.var.2524562.0.0.php |date=10 August 2009 }}, ''Sunday Herald'' 9 August 2009</ref> and abroad.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/12/south-africa-world-cup-2010 World Cup 2010: football brings defining moment for South Africa], 12 June 2009. ''The Guardian'' Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/29/world/africa/29iht-letter.html?_r=1 ''World Cup Whose Meaning Goes Beyond Soccer''], Alan Cowell, 28 December 2009, ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://us.oneworld.net/article/362921-slums-act-will-displace-thousands-south-africa |title=Shack Dwellers Fight Demolition in S. Africa Court |publisher=OneWorld.net |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928224810/http://us.oneworld.net/article/362921-slums-act-will-displace-thousands-south-africa |archivedate=28 September 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-05-16-poohslinging-slums-act-showdown-at-con-court|title=Pooh-slinging Slums Act showdown at Con Court|publisher=M&G}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/10/1/south_africas_poor_targeted_by_evictions|title=South Africa’s Poor Targeted by Evictions, Attacks in Advance of 2010 World Cup by Democracy Now!}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/dec/30/zuma-failing-black-south-africans] Jonathan Steele, ''Why 2010 Could Be An Own Goal for the Rainbow Nation'', The Guardian, 30 December 2009</ref>
==History==
Abahlali's original work was primarily committed to opposing demolitions and forced removals and to struggling for good land and quality housing in the cities.<ref name="How People Face Evictions">[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dpu/k_s/publications/how_ppl_face_evictions How People Face Evictions]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Prof. Yves Cabannes, Development Planning Unit, University College of London (DPU/UCL), May 2011</ref> In most instances this takes the form of a demand for shack settlements to be upgraded with formal housing and services where they are or for new houses to be built close to where the existing settlements are. However the movement has also argued that basic services such as water, electricity and toilets should be immediately provided to shack settlements while land and housing in the city are negotiated. The movement has also engaged in the mass popular appropriation of access to water and electricity.<ref>[http://historymatters.co.za/2008/09/22/a-big-devil-in-the-shacks-the-politics-of-fire/ A big devil in the shacks: The politics of fire]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metamute.org/en/A-Short-History-of-Abahlali-baseMjondolo |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-01-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061013024804/http://www.metamute.org/en/A-Short-History-of-Abahlali-baseMjondolo |archivedate=13 October 2006 }} A-Short-History-of-Abahlali-baseMjondolo</ref>
The movement quickly had a considerable degree of success in stopping evictions and forced removals, winning the right for new shacks to be built as settlements expand and in winning access to basic services,<ref name="thoughtleader.co.za">[http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/imraanbuccus/2009/03/12/durban-breaks-new-ground-in-participatory-democracy/ Durban breaks new ground in participatory democracy, Imraan Buccus]. Thoughtleader.co.za. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> but for three years was not able to win secure access to good urban land for quality housing.<ref>See the COHRE report again</ref> In late 2008 the then AbM President [[S'bu Zikode]]<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/rizkhan/2010/11/2010112362142630788.html South Africa's new apartheid?], Riz Khan, Al Jazeera, 23 November 2010</ref> announced a deal with the eThekwini Municipality which would see services being provided to 14 settlements and tenure security and formal housing to three.<ref>[http://www.africafiles.org/article.asp?ID=19685&ThisURL=./southern.asp&URLName=Southern%20Region Speech by S'bu Zikode]. Africafiles.org (14 December 2008). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> The municipality confirmed this deal in February 2009.<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za">[http://sds.ukzn.ac.za/default.php?3,6,684,4,0 The Work of violence:a timeline of armed attacks at Kennedy Road] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217013112/http://sds.ukzn.ac.za/default.php?3%2C6%2C684%2C4%2C0 |date=17 February 2015 }}, Kerry Chance ''School of Development Studies Research Report'', 83, July 2010.]</ref>
The movement has been involved in considerable conflict with the eThekwini Municipality and has undertaken numerous protests and legal actions against the city authorities.<ref>These are detailed in some of the academic work and there is reference to some of the legal actions in the report on Centre on Housing Rights & Evictions ([[Geneva]]) which is online at {{cite web|url=http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219072803/http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |archivedate=19 December 2008 }}. The papers from many of the court actions are also archived on the Abahlali site</ref> Its members have been beaten and many of its leaders arrested by the [[South African Police Service]] in Sydenham, Durban.<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2006-09-16-i-was-punched-beaten Niren Tolsi, 'I was punched, beaten'], ''Mail & Guardian', 16 September 2007</ref>
Abahlali has often made claims of severe [[police harassment]], including [[torture]].<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/3245 AbM statement on police harassment]</ref> On a number of occasions, these claims have been supported by church leaders<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/2661 A statement against police violence against Abahlali by 11 church leaders]</ref> and human rights organisations.<ref>[http://www.cohre.org/southafrica Relevant Letter and Full Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219072803/http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |date=19 December 2008 }}</ref> The movement has successfully sued the police for unlawful assaults on its members.<ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2013-04-26-00-sa-police-caught-dead-to-rights SA police caught dead to right], by Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'',26 April 2013</ref>
In October 2009, the movement won a constitutional court case which declared the [[KZN Slums Act]] unconstitutional.<ref name="How People Face Evictions"/><ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-05-24-shack-dwellers-victory-bus] 'Shack dwellers' victory bus' by Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 2009</ref><ref name="mg.co.za">[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-10-18-landmark-judgment-in-favour-of-poor Landmark judgment for the poor], Niren Tolsi, Mail & Guardian, 18 October 2009]. Mg.co.za (18 October 2009). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=85924 Ruling in Abahlali case lays solid foundation to build on], Marie Huchzermeyer, ''Business Day'', 04/11/2009</ref> In the same year there was acute conflict between the movement and the [[Cape Town City Council]]<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/taxonomy/term/1255 Collection of articles on the Macassar Village Land Occupation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620091343/http://www.abahlali.org/taxonomy/term/1255 |date=20 June 2009 }}</ref> which centred on the [[Macassar Village Land Occupation]]. There was similar conflict in 2013 which centred on the [[Marikana land occupation (Cape Town)|Marikana Land Occupation]].<ref>[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-05-02-marikana-unfreedom-day-land-occupation-ends-in-violent-workers-day-eviction 'Marikana' UnFreedom Day land occupation ends in violent Workers’ Day eviction], by Jared Sacks, ''The Daily Maverick'', 2 May 2013</ref>
== Autonomy and democracy==
Academic work on the movement stresses that it is non-professionalised (i.e. its leaders are nonsalaried), independent of NGO control, autonomous from political organisations and party politics<ref>[http://abahlali.org/files/Patel%202007%20Electing%20Land%20Questions%20CODESRIA.pdf examining the refusal of electoral politics in Abahlali], Raj Patel</ref><ref name="Analysing Political Subjectivities pp.534-553">Analysing Political Subjectivities: Naming the Post-Development State in Africa Today by Michael Neocosmos, ''Journal of Asian & African Studies'', pp.534–553, Vol. 45, No. 5, October 2010</ref> and democratic.<ref>Raj Patel [http://jas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/43/1/95 'A Short Course in Politics at the University of Abahlali baseMjondolo']. Jas.sagepub.com (1 February 2008). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>Nigel Gibson, [http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a905730486~db=all~order=page 'Upright and free: Fanon in South Africa, from Biko to the shackdwellers' movement (Abahlali baseMjondolo)', ''Social Identities'' (Volume 14, Issue 6 November 2008 , pages 683 – 715)]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdonline.org/45/gibson.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129065924/http://sdonline.org/45/gibson.htm |archivedate=29 November 2010 }} 'Zabalaza, Unfinished Struggles against Apartheid: The Shackdwellers’ Movement in Durban', Nigel Gibson, Socialism & Democracy</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110726075204/http://www.gdri-africancities.org/uploads/uploads/2008-GDRI-informality%20paper%20revised%204-12-08.doc%20-%20Huch.doc Settlement Informality: The importance of understanding change, formality and land and the informal economy], [[Marie Huchzermeyer]], 2008</ref><ref name=ncg>Nigel C. Gibson, Living Fanon: Interdisciplinary Perspectives (2011: London, Palgrave Macmillan)</ref> Sarah Cooper-Knock describes the movement as "neurotically democratic, impressively diverse and steadfastly self-critical".<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>[http://www.dailynews.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=5243863 Symbol of hope silenced], Sarah Cooper-Knock, ''Daily News'', 13 November 2009</ref> Ercument Celik writes that "I experienced how democratically the movement ran its meetings."<ref>[Street Traders: A Bridge Between Trade Unions and Social Movements in Contemporary South Africa], by Ercument Celik, Nomos, Freiburg, 2009, p. 175-176</ref>
The movement has, along with the [[Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]], refused to work with the NGO-run 'Social Movements Indaba' (SMI), and some of the NGOs involved with the SMI.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://antieviction.org.za/2007/02/12/african-movements-continue-their-fights-against-ngo-authoritarianism/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501130830/http://antieviction.org.za/2007/02/12/african-movements-continue-their-fights-against-ngo-authoritarianism/ |archivedate=1 May 2009 |df=dmy }} AEC statement on the SMI</ref> The movement has been particularly critical of the Centre for Civil Society at the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal]]<ref>[http://www.diakonia.org.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=61&Itemid=63] 'Land and Housing: the burning questions', The Diakonia Council of Churches Economic Justice Lecture, 28 August 2008</ref> and refuses to work with the Centre.<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/269] Supporting Abahlali baseMjondolo</ref>
== Membership and structures == {{See also|Abahlali baseMjondolo (Membership & Structures)}}
In 2010 the movement claimed to have around 25,000 active supporters in 64 different shack settlements of which just over 10 000 were paid up card carrying members.<ref>[http://sds.ukzn.ac.za/default.php?2,4,80,4,0 The Work of violence:a timeline of armed attacks at Kennedy Road] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826221439/http://sds.ukzn.ac.za/default.php?2%2C4%2C80%2C4%2C0 |date=26 August 2011 }} by Kerry Chance, School of Development Studies Research Report, 83, July 2010.]</ref> The movement has affiliated settlements and branches in non-affiliated settlements and also a has a youth league and a women's league.<ref>Vos, Pierre De. (2010-09-09) [http://constitutionallyspeaking.co.za/in-defense-of-the-internet/ Pierre de Vos In defense of the Internet]. Constitutionallyspeaking.co.za. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
== Campaigns ==
Since 2005, the movement has carried out a series of large scale marches,<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>[http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/comment/49497] Resistance from the other South Africa by Neha Nimmagudda in Pambazuka News(2008-07-17]</ref> created numerous dual power institutions<ref name="ReferenceB">See 'Rights, democracy, social movements: Abahlali baseMjondolo – a living politics' Masters Thesis by Matt Birkinshaw, University of London, 2007</ref> and engaged in direct action such as land occupations<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1111/S00774/occupy-durban-abahlali-basemjondolo-press-statement.htm Occupy Durban], AbM Press Statement, December 2011</ref> and self organised water and electricity connections and made tactical use of the courts.<ref>[http://www.seri-sa.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26&Itemid=3 Civic Action and Legal Mobilisation: the Phiri water meters case], Jackie Dugard, Wits University, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.seri-sa.org/images/stories/siyanda_mediastatement_sep12final.pdf Victory for the Forgotten Shack Dwellers], Socio-Economic Rights Institute of South Africa, 19 September 2012</ref><ref name="Judgment a victory for 38 families">[http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/judgment-a-victory-for-38-families-1.1387449#.UHLAupjMhlE Judgment a victory for 38 families], ''Daily News'', 20 September 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-10-04-a-durban-shack-dwellers-movement-tells-of-ancs-woes/ A Durban shack dweller's movement tells of ANC's woes], Khadija Patel, ''The Daily Maverick'', 4 October 2013</ref> The movement has often made [[anti-capitalist]] statements,<ref>[http://www.champnetwork.org/solidarity_project/2008/05/en/abahlali-basemjondolo-%E2%80%93-the-south-african-shack-dwellers-mov 'Abahlali baseMjondolo – The South African Shack Dwellers Movement' by Suzy Subways, 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003034916/http://www.champnetwork.org/solidarity_project/2008/05/en/abahlali-basemjondolo-%E2%80%93-the-south-african-shack-dwellers-mov |date=3 October 2009 }}. Champnetwork.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> has called for "a living communism",<ref>[http://www.diakonia.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=129&Itemid=54] Text of Speech at Diakonia Economic Justice Forum – Please follow the link to the PDF for the full content of the speech</ref><ref>[http://www.socialtextjournal.org/periscope/2011/05/politics-of-grieving---drucilla-cornell.php Politics of Grieving] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126053228/http://www.socialtextjournal.org/periscope/2011/05/politics-of-grieving---drucilla-cornell.php |date=26 January 2012 }}, by [[Drucilla Cornell]], ''Social Text'', 2011</ref> and has demanded the [[Nationalization|expropriation]] of private land for public housing.<ref>[http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=833970 ‘The poor need proper homes’ – article in the Sowetan by Mary Papayya 1 September 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911234712/http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=833970 |date=11 September 2008 }}</ref>
Abahlali historically refused to participate in party politics<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/510] Article by M'du Hlongwa examining the refusal of electoral politics in Abahlali</ref> or any NGO-style professionalisation or individualisation of struggle and instead sought to build democratic people's power where people lived and worked.<ref>[http://www.cpp.org.za/main.php?include=publications/critical_dialogue/vol2no1_2006/main.html&menu=_menu/about.html&title=Search] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328104242/http://www.cpp.org.za/main.php?include=publications%2Fcritical_dialogue%2Fvol2no1_2006%2Fmain.html&menu=_menu%2Fabout.html&title=Search |date=28 March 2012 }} Article by Xin Wei Ngiam in Critical Dialogue (Vol.2, No.1, 2006) that includes interviews on conceptions of democracy amongst Abahlali militants.</ref><ref>[http://clandestino.carta.org/2010/05/14/welcome-abahlali-tuesday-18-press-conference/ Clandestino]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Carta Magazine</ref> Academic work claims that the movement has protected its autonomy from political parties and NGOs.<ref>Street Traders: A Bridge Between Trade Unions and Social Movements in Contemporary South Africa, by Ercument Celik, Nomos, Freiburg, 2009</ref><ref name="Analysing Political Subjectivities pp.534-553"/> However, in 2014, Abahlali was critiqued for endorsing the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] in the 2014 national elections.<ref name="iol.co.za">[http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/da-signs-pact-with-kzn-landless-people-1.1682799#.U2QHrMZCC8E] DA signs pact with KZN landless people, 2 May 2014</ref> Nonetheless Abahlali announced it endorsed the Democratic Alliance in the 2014 national election solely as part of a strategy to vote out any standing party that fails to deliver on its political promises <ref>http://www.groundup.org.za/article/why-abahlali-endorsed-da-sbu-zikode-speaks-groundup/</ref>
===Land and housing===
The movement campaigns for well located urban land for public housing<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/24/south-africa-shack-bahlali-basejondolo South Africa's shack-dwellers fight back], by Patrick Kingsely, ''The Guardian'', 24 September 2012</ref> and has occupied unused government land.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/13212 'Black Boers' clear townships by force] by Ruth Maclean, ''The Times'', London, 22 November 2013</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/11/south-africa-fight-decent-housing-assassination Despite the state's violence, our fight to escape the mud and fire of South Africa's slums will continue], S'bu Zikode, ''The Guardian'', 11 November 2013</ref>
A primary demand of the movement has been for decent, public housing and much of its work takes the form of opposing evictions.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/opinion/serving-public-interest-cairo%E2%80%99s-urban-development Serving the public interest in Cairo’s urban development], by Jessie McClelland, al Masryalyoum, 12/05/2010</ref> The movement has often used the phrase '[[The Right to the City]]'<ref>[http://base.d-p-h.info/es/fiches/dph/fiche-dph-8059.html ''The Abahlali baseMjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement and the Right to the City in South Africa''] by Charlotte Mathivet and Shelley Buckingham, Habitat International Coalition, 2009</ref> to insist that the location of housing is critically important and demands that shack settlements are upgraded where they are and that people are not relocated to out of town developments.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/3208] This emerges clearly in the archive of the movement's memoranda and press statements</ref><ref>There is reference to some of the legal actions against evictions in the 2008 report on housing rights in Durban Centre on Housing Rights & Evictions (Geneva) which is online at {{cite web|url=http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219072803/http://www.cohre.org/southafrica |archivedate=19 December 2008 }}. The papers from many of the court actions are also archived on the Abahlali site</ref> The movement rejects technocratic approaches to the housing crisis and stresses the need for dignity to be central to the resolution of the housing crisis.<ref>Love in the Time of AIDS, Mark Hunter, UKZN Press, 2010, p.224</ref> It is opposed to shack dwellers being moved into 'transit camps'.<ref name="Judgment a victory for 38 families"/>
The movement opposes all evictions and forced removals and has campaigned vigorously on this score via public protest and, also, legal action.<ref name="abahlali.org"/><ref>[http://www.legalbrief.co.za/article.php?story=20080924134340977] For a discussion of a key court victory against evictions see the article 'Chetty Champions the Poor' in 'South African Legal Brief', 24 September 2008</ref>
===Service delivery===
The movement has also campaigned for the provision of basic services to shack settlements.<ref name="abahlali.org">[http://abahlali.org/node/3208] This also emerges very clearly in the archive of the movement's memoranda and press statements</ref><ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-12-18-capitalism-the-real-culprit-behind-climate-change] Capitalism the 'real culprit behind climate change' by Faranaaz Parker, Mail & Guardian, 18 December 2009</ref>
In South Africa, there are an average of "ten shack fires a day with someone dying in a shack fire every other day".<ref name="pambazuka.org">[http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/comment/50572 Matt Birkinshaw 'The Big Devil in the Jondolos: The Politics of Shack Fires in Pambazuka News (2008)]. Pambazuka.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> Abahlali has campaigned on this issue demanding, amongst other things, the electrification of shacks.<ref>See http://abahlali.org/search/node/fire</ref> It has also connected thousands of people to electricity.<ref name="pambazuka.org"/>
The movement campaigns for equal access to school education for poor children.<ref>[http://www.teachersolidarity.com/blog/south-african-social-movement-campaigns-against-school-exclusions/ South African Social Movement campaigns against School Exclusions], ''Teacher Solidarity'', 9 January 2011</ref>
===Dual power and the refusal of electoral politics===
Since 2005, Abahlali baseMjondolo refused to vote in all state elections.<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>[http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2008/12/415682.html Speech by S'bu Zikode, December 2008]. Indymedia.org.uk (17 December 2008). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> The movement stated that it aimed, instead, to use [[direct democracy]] to build a counter power to that of the state by creating a series of linked collectives and communes. This position is shared by all the organisations in the Poor People's Alliance.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/files/Patel%202007%20Electing%20Land%20Questions%20CODESRIA.pdf] See [[Raj Patel]],'Electing Land Questions: A Methodological Discussion with Reference to Abahlali baseMjondolo, the Durban Shack dwellers' Movement', [[Codesria]], 2007</ref><ref name="ekklesia.co.uk">[http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/9282] Grassroots movements plan to boycott South African poll ''Ekklesia'', 29 April 2009</ref> However, in 2014 it abandoned this position and urged its members to vote for the Democratic Alliance.<ref name="iol.co.za"/>
===Mutual aid===
The movement has organised a number of mutual aid projects: crèches, kitchens and vegetable gardens.<ref>[http://www.timeslive.co.za/lifestyle/article600245.ece/Seeds-of-rebellion Seeds of rebellion], by Albert Buhr, ''The Times'', 15 August 2010</ref>
===The KZN Slums Act===
{{See also|KZN Slums Act}}
Abahlali baseMjondolo took the Provincial Government of KwaZulu-Natal to court to have the controversial<ref>[http://www.perspectivesonglobalissues.com/0301/southafrica.htm The KwaZulu-Natal Slums Bill: An Illustration of an Institutional Shift in Democracy], by Mikelle Adgate, Scot Dalton, Betsy Fuller Matambanadzo, ''Perspectives on Global Issues'', Fall, 2008</ref><ref>[[Marie Huchzermeyer]], ''Cities with ‘Slums’: From Informal Settlement Eradication to a Right To The City In Africa''] University of Cape Town Press, Cape Town, 2011</ref> Slums Act<ref>[https://archive.is/20120716215232/http://web.wits.ac.za/Academic/Centres/CALS/HousingAndEvictions/HousingAbahlali.htm Text of the Slums Bill and other Documents]. Web.wits.ac.za. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> declared unconstitutional.<ref>The complete text of the Act, and the legal papers from Abahlali and the state are all archived at http://abahlali.org/node/1629</ref><ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2008-02-15-shack-dwellers-take-on-slums-act] Shack dwellers take on Slums Act by Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 14 February 2008</ref> but lost the case.<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/topstories.aspx?ID=BD4A992159 Constitutional challenge to law on slums], Ernest Mabuza, Business Day, 4 May 2009 {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> On 14 May 2009, it took the case on appeal to the Constitutional Court.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=139&art_id=vn20090515062445131C513091&set_id=] 'Three provinces protest against slum bill', by Bonile Ngqiyaza, ''The Star'', 15 May 2009</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8049449.stm South Africa shanty town bill row, BBC, 15 May 2009]. BBC News (14 May 2009). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://us.oneworld.net/article/362921-slums-act-will-displace-thousands-south-africa Shack Dwellers Fight Demolition in S. Africa Court] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928224810/http://us.oneworld.net/article/362921-slums-act-will-displace-thousands-south-africa |date=28 September 2011 }}, One World, 15 May 2009. Us.oneworld.net. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> Judgment was handed down on 14 October 2009 and the movement won the case with costs.<ref name="mg.co.za"/><ref>[http://www.utrechtlawreview.org/index.php/ulr/article/viewFile/162/161 ‘From shack to the Constitutional Court’: The litigious disruption of governing global cities], by Anna Selmeczi, ''Utrecht Law Review'', April 2011</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110430042505/http://blog.nibrinternational.no/#post40 So what difference does it make? Socio-economic rights and democratising development in South Africa], Peris Jones, Norwegian Institute for Urban and Regional Research, 27 April 2011</ref>
===Xenophobia and police brutality===
The movement took a strong stand against the [[Xenophobia in South Africa|xenophobic attacks]] that swept the country in May 2008<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref name="Analysing Political Subjectivities pp.534-553"/><ref>See http://www.abahlali.org/node/3582</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fpif.org/fpiftxt/5767 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113202724/http://www.fpif.org/fpiftxt/5767 |archivedate=13 January 2009 }}'The Africa that Pushes Back' by Mukoma Wa Ngugi, Foreign Policy in Focus, 24 December 2008</ref> and there were no attacks in any Abahlali settlements.<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>[http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/features/48712] 'The politics of fear and the fear of politics' by [[Michael neocosmos|Michael Neocosmos]], Pambazuka, 2008</ref><ref>''From 'Foreign Natives' to 'Native Foreigners': Explaining Xenophobia in Post-Apartheid South Africa'', Michael Neocosmos, CODESRIA, Dakar, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.ru.ac.za/politics/events/seminarseries “We are Gauteng People” Challenging the politics of xenophobia in Khutsong, South Africa] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802111842/http://www.ru.ac.za/politics/events/seminarseries |date=2 August 2010 }}, Seminar Presentation, Joshua Kirshner, 23 February 2011, Rhodes University</ref> The movement was also able to stop an in-progress attack in the (non-Abahlali affiliated) Kenville settlement and to offer shelter to some people displaced in the attacks.<ref>See 'The Politics of Fear and the Fear of Politics: Reflections on Xenophobic Violence in South Africa', an article by Professor Michael Neocosmos from Monash University in Australia in the Journal of Asian & African Studies Vol. 43, No. 6, 586–594 (2008)</ref><ref>[http://sanhati.com/articles/843/ 'The May 2008 Pogroms: xenophobia, evictions, liberalism, and democratic grassroots militancy in South Africa' by Richard Pithouse, in ''Sanhati'', June 2008]. Sanhati.com. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
The movement has organised numerous actions against police racism and brutality<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/991 See, for instance, Against Police Brutality – March On Glen Nayager, 10 April 2007]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> and has often demanded fair access to policing services for shack dwellers.<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/>
===The University of Abahlali baseMjondolo===
The movement runs formal courses and issues certification for these. It also hosts regular seminars.<ref>Nigel Gibson, 'Upright and free: Fanon in South Africa, from Biko to the shackdwellers' movement (Abahlali baseMjondolo)', ''Social Identities'' (Volume 14, Issue 6 November 2008 , pages 683 – 715)</ref> The movement reports that topics covered have ranged from computer skills<ref name="ReferenceC"/> to training in safely connecting shacks to water and electricity, to questions of law and policy, to political ideas like the right to the city, questions of political strategy and to the work of a philosopher like [[Jacques Ranciere]].<ref>[Various entries at Abahlali baseMjondolo http://www.abahlali.org]</ref><ref>[http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20130524144726593 Transforming the basis of knowledge], Budd Hall, ''University World News'', 25 May 2013</ref>
===2010 FIFA World Cup===
Abahlali baseMjondolo of the Western Cape threatened to build shacks outside of the Cape Town stadium to draw attention to their situation<ref name="libcom.org">[http://libcom.org/news/quiet-coup-south-africa%E2%80%99s-largest-social-movement-under-attack-world-cup-looms-02062010 A Quiet Coup: South Africa’s largest social movement under attack as the World Cup Looms] Toussaint Losier, ''Left Turn Magazine'', June 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1147414 Shack dwellers threat to Cup] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626141621/http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1147414 |date=26 June 2010 }} Francis Hweshe, ''The Sowetan'', 1 June 2010</ref> but were not able to make good on this threat.<ref>[http://worldwidesocialist.net/blog/2010/07/south-africa-from-polokwane-to-the-world-cup-and-after/ South Africa: from Polokwane to the World Cup and after] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712074425/http://worldwidesocialist.net/blog/2010/07/south-africa-from-polokwane-to-the-world-cup-and-after/ |date=12 July 2010 }}, Martin Legassick, ''World Wide Socialist Network'', 9 July 2010</ref>
== Philosophy ==
The movement describes itself as "a homemade politics that everyone can understand and find a home in"<ref>[http://www.metamute.org/en/Thinking-Resistance-in-the-Shanty-Town Richard Pithouse' Thinking Resistance in the Shantytown', [[Mute Magazine]], August 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025005905/http://www.metamute.org/en/Thinking-Resistance-in-the-Shanty-Town |date=25 October 2008 }}</ref> and stresses that it moves from the lived experience of the poor to create a politics that is both intellectual and actional.<ref>[http://www.spatialagency.net/database/abahlali.basemjondolo Abahlali baseMjondolo, Spatial Agency]. Spatialagency.net. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
Its philosophy has been sketched out in a number of articles and interviews. The key ideas are those of a politics of the poor, a living politics and a people's politics.<ref>[http://jas.sagepub.com/content/47/5/498.abstract Abahlali’s Vocal Politics of Proximity: Speaking, Suffering and Political Subjectivization], Anna Selmeczi, ''Journal of Asian and African Studies'', October 2012 vol. 47 no. 5 498-515</ref> A politics of the poor is understood to mean a politics that is conducted by the poor and for the poor in a manner that enables the poor to be active participants in the struggles conducted in their name. Practically, it means that such a politics must be conducted where poor people live or in places that they can easily access, at the times when they are free, in the languages that they speak. It does not mean that middle-class people and organisations are excluded but that they are expected to come to these spaces and to undertake their politics there in a dialogical and democratic manner. There are two key aspects to the idea of a living politics. The first is that it is understood as a politics that begins not from external theory but from the experience of the people that shape it. It is argued that political education usually operates to create new elites who mediate relationships of [[patronage]] upwards and who impose ideas on others and to exclude ordinary people from thinking politically. This politics is not anti-theory – it just asserts the need to begin from lived experience and to move on from there rather than to begin from theory (usually imported from the [[Global North]]) and to impose theory on the lived experience of suffering and resistance in the shacks. The second key aspect, of a living politics, is that political thinking is always undertaken democratically and in common. People's politics is opposed to party politics or politicians' politics (as well as to top down undemocratic forms of NGO politics) and it is argued that the former is a popular democratic project undertaken without financial reward and with an explicit refusal of representative roles and personal power while the latter is a top down, professionalised representative project driven by personal power.<ref>The movement's philosophy is clearly articulated in a number of statements on its website – see, especially, the statements at http://abahlali.org/node/3208 It is also usefully summarised in the academic work by Nigel Gibson</ref><ref>[http://www.cpp.org.za/main.php?include=publications/critical_dialogue/vol2no1_2006/main.html&menu=_menu/about.html&title=Search] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328104242/http://www.cpp.org.za/main.php?include=publications%2Fcritical_dialogue%2Fvol2no1_2006%2Fmain.html&menu=_menu%2Fabout.html&title=Search |date=28 March 2012 }} Also see 'Taking poverty seriously: What the poor are saying and why it matters' by Xin Wei Ngiam in Critical Dialogue, Vol.2, No.1, 2006</ref><ref>[http://davidharvey.org/2010/06/interface-journal-debates-david-harvey/] Educating resistance by Anna Anna Selmeczi in Debating David Harvey in Interface Journal (pp. 309 – 314), Volume 2 issue 1 (May 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/ftinterface~content=a915734169~fulltext=713240930~frm=content] We are being left to burn because we do not count: Biopolitics, Abandonment, and Resistance by Anna Selmeczi in Global Society, Volume 23, Issue 4 October 2009 , pages 519 – 538</ref>
While the movement is clear that its key immediate goals are 'land and housing' it is equally clear that it sees its politics as going beyond this.<ref name="Politics of Grieving">[http://www.socialtextjournal.org/periscope/2011/05/politics-of-grieving---drucilla-cornell.php Politics of Grieving] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126053228/http://www.socialtextjournal.org/periscope/2011/05/politics-of-grieving---drucilla-cornell.php |date=26 January 2012 }}, by Drucilla Cornell, ''Social Text'', 2011</ref> S'bu Zikode has commented that: "We have seen in certain cases in South Africa where governments have handed out houses simply to silence the poor. This is not acceptable to us. Abahalali’s struggle is beyond housing. We fight for respect and dignity. If houses are given to silence the poor then those houses are not acceptable to us."<ref>[http://edinburghanarchists.noflag.org.uk/2010/07/south-africa-talk-follow-up/#more-391 Report on the Attack on Abahlali baseMjonolo in the Kennedy Road settlement by the Development Planning Unit of University College London] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101016082629/http://edinburghanarchists.noflag.org.uk/2010/07/south-africa-talk-follow-up/#more-391 |date=16 October 2010 }}, by Malavika Vartak, 2009</ref>
'Abahlalism' has on occasion been described as anarchist or [[autonomist]] in practice.<ref>http://abahlali.org/node/7619 Morgan Rodgers Gibson (2010) 'Anarchism, the State and the Praxis of Contemporary Antisystemic Social Movements', [[Website of Abahlali baseMjondolo]], December, 2010]</ref><ref>[http://shwagr.com/posts/modern-anarchist-societies-series-abahlali-basemjondolo-the-autonomous-exemplars-of-south-africa Modern Anarchist Societies Series – Abahlali baseMjondolo || The Autonomous Exemplars of South Africa] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716064459/http://shwagr.com/posts/modern-anarchist-societies-series-abahlali-basemjondolo-the-autonomous-exemplars-of-south-africa |date=16 July 2011 }}. Shwagr.com. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> This is primarily because its praxis correlates closely with central tenets of [[anarchism]], including decentralisation, opposition to imposed hierarchy, direct democracy and recognition of the connection between means and ends.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/6664#attachments Morgan Rodgers Gibson (2009) 'The Role of Anarchism in Contemporary Anti-Systemic Social Movements', [[Website of Abahlali baseMjondolo]], December, 2009]</ref> However, the movement has never described itself as either anarchist or autonomist. Zikode has said that the movement aspires to 'a living communism'.<ref name="Politics of Grieving"/>
==Elections==
The movement, together with similar grassroots movements in [[Johannesburg]] and [[Cape Town]],<ref>[http://sacsis.org.za/site/article/245.1] Elections: A Dangerous Time for Poor People's Movements in South Africa</ref> takes a very critical stance towards state elections in South Africa. They have boycotted the local government elections in 2006,<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/865] "No Vote” Campaigns are not a Rejection of Democracy, November 2005</ref> the national government elections in 2009 and the 2011 local government elections<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/w-cape-voters-not-predictable-1.1070406?showComments=true W Cape voters ‘not predictable’], Quinton Mtyala and Babalo Ndenze, ''The Cape Argus'', 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/kwazulu-natal/no-land-no-house-no-vote-1.1070896 ‘No Land! No House! No Vote!’], ''The Mercury'', By SINEGUGU NDLOVU AND BRONWYN FOURIE, 19 May 2011</ref> under the banner of [[No Land! No House! No Vote!]]. It has been reported that "Nearly 75% of South Africans aged 20-29 did not vote in the 2011 [local government] elections" and that "South Africans in that age group were more likely to have taken part in violent street protests against the local ANC than to have voted for the ruling party".<ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2013-01-29-deep-read-anc-risks-losing-born-free-voters Deep Read: 'Born free' voters may not choose ANC], JON HERSKOVITZ, ''Mail & Guardian'', 29 January 2013</ref>
The philosophy of Abahlali baseMjondolo with regards to elections can be summarised by the following statement from its elected president [[S'bu Zikode]],<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2010/09/07/slums-underground-economy-2020-opinions-contributors-robert-neuwirth.html Economies Go Underground][[Robert Neuwirth]], [[Forbes]], 09.09.10,</ref> "The government and academics speak about the poor all the time, but so few want to speak to the poor...It becomes clear that our job is just to vote and then watch the rich speak about us as we get poorer".<ref name="sundayherald.com"/>
The movement's Deputy President, Lindela Figlan has argued that “Voting someone into government just gives them power to oppress and exploit us.”<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/opinion/be-angry-with-government-not-cops-1.1651036#.Uwh0-mKSx1V Be angry with government, not cops], Lee Rondganger, Lyse Comins and Nosipho Mngoma, ''The Daily News'', 2014</ref>
Despite this sentiment, at the Abahlali baseMjondolo "Unfreedom Day" rally held in Kwa-Mashu on 27 April 2014, the movement's President Sbu Zikode announced that they "would abandon their No Land, No House, No Vote campaign and cast a “strategic vote” in the May 7 elections".<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/we-will-vote-but-not-anc-abahlali-1.1681690#.U2PHX3V52Dc We will vote, but not ANC: Abahali], Nosipho Mngoma, ''The Daily News'', 29 April 2014</ref> A few days later Zikode signed a pact with the centrist [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] (DA), stating that "We encourage our comrades and our membership to vote for the Democratic Alliance so that we can get rid of corruption".<ref name="dailynews_02052014" /> Zikode clarified that "Abahlali are not joining DA or any political party. We will remain independent from all kinds of mainstream political parties. But this time around it's a tactical partnership where the aim is to really get rid of the party that has become a threat to the society".<ref name="ecn_02052014" /> The DA welcomed Abahali's endorsement, stating that this had come after two years of engagement.<ref>[http://www.da.org.za/newsroom.htm?action=view-news-item&id=13729 Abahlali Basemjondolo publicly endorse the DA for the elections] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503000409/http://www.da.org.za/newsroom.htm?action=view-news-item&id=13729 |date=3 May 2014 }} Sizwe Mchunu, DA Leader in KwaZulu-Natal, 2 May 2014</ref>
== Repression ==
In the early days of the movement, individuals in the ruling party often accused Abahlali of being criminals manipulated by a malevolent white man, a '[[Third Force (South Africa)|third force]]', or a foreign intelligence agency.<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref name=ncg/><ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/17] Article by S'bu Zikode written in response to Third Force allegations</ref>
The movement, like others in South Africa,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012021959/http://www.fxi.org.za/content/view/49/51/ See a report in illegal police repression in South Africa by the Freedom of Expression Institute]. Fxi.org.za (9 November 2011). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref name="Dissent Under Thabo Mbeki">[https://www.ru.ac.za/documents/Politics/Duncan_Dissent_Under_Mbeki%5B1%5D.doc Dissent Under Thabo Mbeki]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Jane Duncan, May 2011</ref> has suffered sustained illegal harassment from the state<ref>Nigel C. Gibson, ''Living Fanon: Interdisciplinary Perspectives'' (2011: London, Palgrave Macillan)</ref> that has resulted in more than 200 arrests of Abahlali members in the first last three years of its existence and repeated [[police brutality]] in people's homes, in the streets and in detention.<ref>Shack Dwellers on the Move in Durban, Richard Pithouse, ''Radical Philosophy'', 2007</ref> On a number of occasions, the police used live ammunition,<ref name="Dissent Under Thabo Mbeki"/> [[armoured vehicle]]s and helicopters in their attacks on unarmed shack dwellers.<ref>[http://www.nu.ac.za/ccs/files/RReport3a.pdf Yonk'indawo Umzabalazo Uyasivumela: New work from Durban, Research Report]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. (PDF) . Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> In 2006 the local city manager, [[Michael Sutcliffe|Mike Sutcliffe]], unlawfully implemented a complete ban on Abahlali's right to march<ref>This is discussed in the Journal of Asian & African Studies Feb 2008; vol. 43: pp. 63 – 94.http://jas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/43/1/63{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071023111324/http://www.fxi.org.za/PDFs/ACP/Shackdwellers/Mike%20Sutcliffe%20letter%202.pdf Also see a letter from the Freedom of Expression Institute, 23 February 2008, which gives a detailed chronology of the banning of one march]. (PDF) . Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> which was eventually overturned in court.<ref name="Dissent Under Thabo Mbeki"/><ref>[http://www.dailynews.co.za/index.php?fSectionId=500&fArticleId=3135023] Article in the Daily News</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024659/http://www.fxi.org.za/content/view/68/51/ Statement by the Freedom of Expression Institute]. Fxi.org.za (9 November 2011). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=77610] Will Zuma administration open its ears to the streets?, Jane Duncan, Business Day, 4 August 2009]</ref> Abahlali have been violently prevented from accepting invitations to appear on television<ref>[http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/features/64054] Richard Pithouse, 'South Africa: Freedom not yet', ''Pambazuka'', 29 April 2010</ref><ref>[http://secure.financialmail.co.za/06/0217/currents/acurrent.htm BATTLE TO BE HEARD] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120718071806/http://secure.financialmail.co.za/06/0217/currents/acurrent.htm |date=18 July 2012 }}, by Carol Paton, ''Financial Mail'', 16 February 2006</ref> and radio debates by the local police.<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2006-09-16-i-was-punched-beaten 'I was punched, beaten'], Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 16 September 2006,</ref> The Freedom of Expression Institute has issued a number of statements in strong support of Abahlali's right to speak out and to organise protests.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024659/http://www.fxi.org.za/content/view/68/51/] Freedom of Expression Institute statement</ref><ref>[http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/naeemjeenah/2007/10/18/free-expression-means-nothing-if-its-limited-to-the-media/] Also see 'Free expression means nothing if it's limited to the media' by Na'eem Jenah, Thought Leader, 18 October 2007</ref> The Centre on Housing Rights and Evictions<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/2664] Open Letter to Obed Mlaba & Mike Sutcliffe by COHRE</ref> and a group of prominent church leaders<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/2661] Testimony by Church Leaders</ref><ref>[http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4068420]{{cite web|url=http://abahlali.org/node/2696 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011223200/http://abahlali.org/node/2696 |archivedate=11 October 2008 }} Sunday Tribune article on church leader's statement</ref> have also issued public statements against police violence, as has Bishop [[Rubin Philip]] in his individual capacity,<ref>[http://www.churchland.co.za/default.asp?id=787]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Unfreedom Day Speech by Bishop Rubin Philip, 27 April 2007</ref> and in support of the right of the movement to publicly express dissent.<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/topstories.aspx?ID=BD4A588878] See'Why we must keep our eyes on the ground' by Professor Stephen Friedman, Business Day, 17 October 2007</ref>
In March 2008, the Mercury newspaper reported that both [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Amnesty International]] were investigating human rights abuses against shack dwellers by the city government.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
In 2009 the movement was attacked in the Kennedy Road settlement - see below.
In April 2010, IRIN, the newsletter of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, reported that "The rise of an organised poor people's movement [Abahlali baseMjondolo] in South Africa's most populous province, KwaZulu-Natal, is being met with increasing hostility by the ruling [[African National Congress]] (ANC) government.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=88883 SOUTH AFRICA: Poor people's movement draws government wrath], IRIN,UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 22 April 2010</ref>
In April 2013 the movement successfully sued the Minister of Police for violence against three of its members.<ref>[http://www.seri-sa.org/index.php/38-latest-news/161-minister-of-police-to-pay-damages-to-abahlali-members-for-police-brutality-22-april-2013 Minister of Police to pay damages to Abahlali members for police brutality], Socio-Economic Rights Institute of South Africa</ref>
On the 26th of June a local AbM leader, Nkululeko Gwala, was assassinated in the Cato Crest shack settlement in Durban.<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/9840 KZN protest leader shot 12 times], Nkululeko Nene, ''Daily News'', 27 June 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-07-31-kzn-anatomy-of-an-assassination KZN: Anatomy of an assassination], Niki Moore, ''Daily Maverick'', 31 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b8a413ee-f855-11e2-92f0-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2dKeHpEuTSouth Africa: Killed for crying foul], by Andrew England, ''Financial Times'', 26 August 2013</ref><ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2013-09-06-00-cato-crest-land-hunger-of-marikana-proportions Cato Crest: Land hunger of 'Marikana' proportions], Manqoba Nxumalo, ''Mail & Guardian'', 6 September 2013</ref>
On 29 September 2014, another Abahlali baseMjondolo member was killed. Thuli Ndlovu, the movement chairperson for KwaNdengezi was assassinated in her home after disputes with a local councillor over housing allocation.<ref>[http://groundup.org.za/article/another-abahlali-basemjondolo-member-assassinated_2308 ''GroundUp'', 1 October 2014]</ref> <ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2014-10-02-tensions-flare-after-hit-on-shack-official/ ''M&G'', 3 October 2014]</ref> Abahlali baseMjondolo accused the councillor of having a hand in the assassination.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/14311/ Thuli Ndlovu was Assassinated last Night, ''Abahlali baseMjondolo'', 30 September 2014]</ref> On 27 February 2015, the local councillor, Mduduzi Ngcobo, was arrested on suspicion of being behind the murder.<ref>[http://www.dailysun.co.za/news/2015-03-03-councillor-bust-for-thulisiles-murder Councillor bust for Thulisile's murder, ''Daily Sun'', 3 March 2015]</ref>
==Church support==
The movement has received strong support from some key church leaders.<ref>[http://www.christiantoday.com/article/a.bishops.pursuit.of.justice.for.south.africas.shack.dwellers/26028.htm] A bishop's pursuit of justice for South Africa's shack dwellers, Emma Pomfret ''Christian Today''</ref> In a speech at the AbM [[UnFreedom Day]] event on 27 April 2008 [[Anglican]] Bishop [[Rubin Phillip]] said that:
"The courage, dignity and gentle determination of Abahlali baseMjodolo has been a light that has shone ever more brightly over the last three years. You have faced fires, sickness, evictions, arrest, beatings, slander, and still you stand bravely for what is true. Your principle that everyone matters, that every life is precious, is very simple but it is also utterly profound. Many of us who hold dear the most noble traditions of our country take hope from your courage and your dignity."<ref>The speech was printed in the May issue of 'Anglican News' and it can be downloaded at http://www.anglican.co.za/archives.htm{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Italian theologian Brother Filippo Mondini has attempted to develop a theology based on the political thought and practices developed in Abahlali baseMjondolo.<ref>[http://www.korogocho.org/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=478:abahlali-basemjondolo-theology&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=76] 'Abahlali basemjondolo Theology' by Filippo Mondini, Korogocho, 26 June 2008</ref>
==Media==
The movement makes considerable use of cellphones to organise, generates its own media where possible<ref name="Post-Apartheid South Africa 2011"/> and has made use of films too.<ref>Sean Jacobs, 'Post-Apartheid Social Movements on Film', ''Popular Media, Democracy and Development in ''Africa, Herman Wasserman (Ed.)Routledge, London, 2010</ref> The award-winning<ref>[http://blog.docfilmsa.com/2011/08/diff-2011-award-winners.html Award-winners at the 32nd Durban International Film Festival]. Blog.docfilmsa.com (1 August 2011). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> documentary feature film ''[[Dear Mandela]]'' tells the story of three young activists in Abahlali baseMjondolo.<ref>[http://www.mahala.co.za/movies/diff-2011-the-wrap-up/#more-19222 DIFF 2011 | The Wrap Up]. Mahala.co.za (3 August 2011). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref><ref>[https://movies.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/movies/dear-mandela-directed-by-dara-kell-and-christopher-nizza.html?_r=0 After Apartheid, More Struggles to Wage], Nicolas Rapold, ''The New York Times'', 20 September 2012</ref>
==The Poor People's Alliance==
In September 2008, the [[Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]], together with Abahlali baseMjondolo, the [[Landless People's Movement]] and the Rural Network (Abahlali baseplasini) formed [[The Poor People's Alliance]]<ref>[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2009/01/12/18562116.php The Struggle for Land & Housing in Post-Apartheid South Africa] by Toussaint Losier, ''Left Turn'', January 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 'Participatory Society: Urban Space & Freedom'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606072510/http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 |date=6 June 2009 }}, by Chris Spannos, Z-Net, 29 May 2009</ref> which is "a co-alition of independent social movements.<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=124776 Voices of poor must be heard], Editorial, ''Business Day'', 25 October 2010</ref> The Poor People's Alliance refuses electoral politics under the banner '[[No Land! No House! No Vote!]]'.<ref name="ekklesia.co.uk"/><ref>The alliance, and its position on electoral politics, is mentioned in the speech by S'bu Zikode at http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2008/12/415682.html</ref><ref>[http://cozop.com/divergences_revue_libertaire_internationale_en_ligne/south_africa_anc_attacks_shack_dwellers_movements ANC Attacks Shack Dwellers Movements]. Cozop.com. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
Abahlali baseMjondolo has also organised in solidarity with the [[South African Unemployed Peoples' Movement|Unemployed Peoples' Movement]].<ref>[http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=54451&CatID=1010 Protests promised over arrest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927092302/http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=54451&CatID=1010 |date=27 September 2013 }}, Dudu Dube, 25 June 2013, ''The New Age''</ref>
==International solidarity==
There is an AbM Solidarity Group in England<ref>[http://www.tmponline.org/2010/03/04/protest-at-zuma%E2%80%99s-uk-visit-in-solidarity-with-south-african-shack-dwellers/ Protest at Zuma’s UK visit in solidarity with South African Shack Dwellers], TMP Online, 3 March 2010</ref> and the movement has links with the following organisations: * [[Domestic Workers United]] in New York<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.domesticworkersunited.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925164744/http://www.domesticworkersunited.org/ |archivedate=25 September 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> * The [[London Coalition Against Poverty]]<ref>[http://www.lcap.org.uk/?p=158 Talk to Us, Not About Us]. Lcap.org.uk (22 August 2009). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[The Poverty Initiative]] in New York<ref>[http://povertyinitiative.org/shackdwellers_movement An Evening with the Shackdwellers Movement of South Africa (20 August 2009)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090822161844/http://www.povertyinitiative.org/shackdwellers_movement |date=22 August 2009 }}. Povertyinitiative.org (20 August 2009). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[Picture the Homeless]] in New York<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/5949 Picture the Homeless Protest in New York City, 9 Oct 2009]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * The [[Movement for Justice in el Barrio]] in New York<ref>[http://latindispatch.com/2010/03/04/zapatista-inspired-rally-held-in-new-york-city-aims-to-fight-gentrification/ Zapatista-Inspired Rally Held in New York City; Aims to Fight Gentrification] by Paola Reyes, Latin Dispatch, 3 March 2010</ref> * [[The Media Mobilizing Project]] in [[Philadelphia]]<ref>[http://mediamobilizing.org/search/node/zikode Media Mobilizing Project]. Mediamobilizing.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[Take Back the Land]] in Miami<ref>[http://takebacktheland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=99:take-back-the-land-in-south-africa&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=60 Take Back the Land in South Africa]. Takebacktheland.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[Sendika]] in [[Istanbul]]<ref>[http://www.sendika.org/yazi.php?yazi_no=17144 Tek bir insan ırkı vardır-Abahlali baseMjondolo (Güney Afrika)]. Sendika.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[The Combined Harare Residents' Association]] in [[Harare]]<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/1493 Combined Harare Residents' Association Visit to Abahlali: mid June 2007]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> * [[Clandestino]] and the [[Comboni Missionaries of the Heart of Jesus|Comboni Missionaries]] in [[Italy]]<ref>[http://clandestino.carta.org/2010/05/19/mondiali-al-contrario-il-doppio-shock/#more-3125 Il doppio shock]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by Gianluca Carmosino, ''Clandestino''</ref> * [[War on Want]] in London<ref>[http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/16960-write-to-the-high-commissioner-to-demand-justice-for-south-africas-poor War on Want Writes to the South African High Commissioner] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727045306/http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/16960-write-to-the-high-commissioner-to-demand-justice-for-south-africas-poor |date=27 July 2010 }}|date=July 2010</ref>
==Criticisms==
According to eThekwini City Manager Dr. Michael Sutcliffe, the essence of the tensions between Abahlali baseMjondolo and the City lie in the fact that the movement "rejects the authority of the city." When the Durban High Court ruled that his attempts to ban marches by Abahlali baseMjondolo were unlawful he stated that: "We will be asking serious questions of the court because we cannot allow anarchy having anyone marching at any time and any place."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.durban.gov.za/durban/government/munadmin/media/press/abmsa?searchterm=abahlali |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726122850/http://www.durban.gov.za/durban/government/munadmin/media/press/abmsa?searchterm=abahlali |archivedate=26 July 2011 }}, Press Statement by Sutcliffe</ref> According to Lennox Mabaso, spokesperson for the Provincial Department of Housing, the movement is "under the sway of an agent provocateur" who is "engaged in clandestine operations" and who has been "assigned to provoke unrest".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://southafrica.indymedia.org/news/2006/10/11358.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319004325/http://southafrica.indymedia.org/news/2006/10/11358.php |archivedate=19 March 2009 }}, Sunday Tribune article by Mabaso</ref> City Officials continue to argue that the movement is a [[Third force (South Africa)|Third Force]] seeking to undermine the ruling [[African National Congress]] for nefarious purposes.<ref>[http://www.witness.co.za/index.php?showcontent&global[_id]=108219 ANC: ‘Abahlali and opposition a third force’], Mhlabunzima Memela, ''The Witness, 17 October 2013</ref>
In December 2006, Abahlali members and members of the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign,<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://abahlali.org/node/462 On the SMI, from the Anti-Eviction Campaign]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> disrupted a meeting of the Social Movements Indaba at the University of KwaZulu Natal and staged a protest.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Some academics and NGO activists, all of whom have clear links to a local NGO, the Centre for Civil Society, claimed that this was criminal behaviour<ref>Setshedi, V. (2006) ‘Report Glosses Over Tsotsi Politics’, Mail and Guardian, 18 December 2006</ref> and somehow illegitimate in that, according to these people, it was in response to the dismissal of four Abahlali linked academics from the Centre. However the WC-AEC issued a statement vigorously rejecting these claims<ref name="ReferenceA"/> while the ''[[Mail and Guardian]]'' newspaper reported a very different account of why Abahlali protested the meeting.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/454 On the far side of left], Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 8 December 2006</ref> A masters thesis by Matt Birkinshaw explained that the protest happened because "Abahlali felt that there was a lack of genuine democracy and participation due to NGO co-optation" in the SMI.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Online video footage of the protest shot by Antonios Vradis indicates that the demonstration was peaceful and rational and that the movements had a clear critique of the NGO co-option of the SMI.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/taxonomy/term/1980 Raw Footage of the Protest at the SMI by the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign and Abahlali baseMjondolo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613124458/http://abahlali.org/taxonomy/term/1980 |date=13 June 2010 }}. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
In October 2010, Abahlali baseMjondolo of the Western Cape called for a month of direct action.<ref>[http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2010/10/04/shack-dwellers-strike-set-to-last-one-month Shack dwellers strike set to last one month], Anna Majavu & Unathi Obose, 4 October 2010</ref><ref>[http://wagingnonviolence.org/2010/11/south-africas-rebellion-of-the-poor/ South Africa’s rebellion of the poor], by Rebecca Burns, ''Waging Non-Violence''</ref> [[Mzonke Poni]], the chairperson of the Cape Town structure at the time, publicly endorsed road blockades as a legitimate tactic during this strike.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/7335 Urgent Call]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> The [[Treatment Action Campaign]] (TAC) and the [[South African Communist Party]], the latter a major ally of the ruling ANC, issued strong statements condemning the campaign and labelling it 'violent'<ref>[http://writingrights.org/2010/10/13/unite-poor-and-working-class-people-reject-abahlali-basemjondolo%E2%80%99s-call-for-violence/ Unite poor and working class people! Reject Abahlali baseMjondolo’s call for violence] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017031139/http://writingrights.org/2010/10/13/unite-poor-and-working-class-people-reject-abahlali-basemjondolo%E2%80%99s-call-for-violence/ |date=17 October 2010 }}. Writingrights.org (13 October 2010). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> and, 'anarchist' and reactionary'.<ref>[http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71654?oid=204883&sn=Detail&pid=71616 Blockading Public Roads is anarchy and reactionary]. Politicsweb.co.za. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> AbM responded by saying that their support for road blockades was not violent and that "We have never called for violence. Violence is harm to human beings. Blockading a road is not violence."<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/7364 Abahlali baseMjondolo of the Western Cape Replies to the Treatment Action Campaign]. Abahlali.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> They also said that the SACP's attack was really due to the movement's insistence on organising autonomously from the [[African National Congress]].<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/7375 Abahlali baseMjondolo of the Western Cape Responds to the South African Communist Party]. Abahlali.org (18 October 2010). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> After the strike by AbM Western Cape, there were some protests in TR section of Khayelitsha in which vehicles were damaged. AbM WC ascribed these protests to the [[ANC Youth League]]<ref>[http://www.khayelitshastruggles.com/2010/11/protests-in-tr-section-today-are.html The Protests in TR Section Today Are Organised by the ANC Youth League and Not by AbM Western Cape] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202053904/http://www.khayelitshastruggles.com/2010/11/protests-in-tr-section-today-are.html |date=2 December 2010 }}. Khayelitshastruggles.com (12 November 2010). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> as did [[Helen Zille]] and the Youth League itself.<ref>[http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71654?oid=211961&sn=Detail&pid=71616 Ungovernability in Cape Town]. Politicsweb.co.za. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> According to ''Leadership Magazine'' "The ANC Youth League in the province has hijacked the peaceful service-delivery protests organised by the social movement Abahlali baseMjondolo in Khayelitsha in a violent, destructive and desperate attempt to mobilise support for the ANC against the province's Democratic Alliance provincial and municipal governments."<ref>[http://www.leadershiponline.co.za/articles/politics/1002-ancs-reshuffle ANC’s reshuffle] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124120314/http://leadershiponline.co.za/articles/politics/1002-ancs-reshuffle |date=24 November 2010 }}. Leadershiponline.co.za (23 November 2010). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref>
==Violence at the Kennedy Road settlement == {{See also|Attack on Kennedy Road}}
