On 26 September 2009, it was reported that at about 11 pm that evening a group of about 40 people entered the Kennedy Road settlement wielding guns and knives and attacked an Abahlali baseMjondolo youth meeting.<ref name="sabarometerblog.wordpress.com"/><ref>[http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=H-SAfrica&month=0912&week=b&msg=W/SUmqooLlQQ7RyZ8XEs2Q Report: Experiences of Abahlali baseMjondolo in Durban, South Africa], by Malavika Vartak, Development Planning Unit of University College London</ref> The attackers chanted ethnic and ANC slogans, demolished residents' homes and threatened to kill named individuals.<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/> At about 5 am the next morning two people were killed in the resulting conflict.<ref name="libcom.org"/> According to an Abahlali baseMjondolo press statement issued on 27 September 2009 "As far as we know two of the attackers were killed when people managed to take their bush knives off them. This was self defence.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/5770 Kennedy Road Development Committee Attacked – People Have Been Killed], 27 September 2009</ref>
It was reported by members of the Abahlali baseMjondolo movement that the attackers were affiliated with the local branch of the [[African National Congress]] and it was claimed that the attack was carefully planned and sanctioned by the local police.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/94212f4a70a54a77a811b7fb94c15069/28-09-2009-10-36/Dbn_attackers_associated_with_ANC |title='Attackers associated with ANC' |publisher=News24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105235359/http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/94212f4a70a54a77a811b7fb94c15069/28-09-2009-10-36/Dbn_attackers_associated_with_ANC |archivedate=5 January 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://antieviction.org.za/2009/09/28/joint-statement-on-the-attacks-on-the-kennedy-road-informal-settlement-in-durban/ |title=Joint Statement on the attacks on the Kennedy Road Informal Settlement in Durban |publisher=Professor John Dugard SC, et al |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018040141/http://antieviction.org.za/2009/09/28/joint-statement-on-the-attacks-on-the-kennedy-road-informal-settlement-in-durban/ |archivedate=18 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> However this was denied by the ANC and the police who blamed a 'forum' associated with Abahlali baseMjondolo for the violence.<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-10-03-ethnic-tension-boils-over Ethnic Tensions Boil Over, Niren Tolsi, Mail & Guardian, 3 October 2009]. Mg.co.za (3 October 2009). Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> However academic research confirmed that the attackers did self identify as ANC members and that ANC leaders at Municipal and Provincial level later provided public sanction for the attack.<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/><ref>[https://www.ru.ac.za/documents/Politics/KERRY%20CHANCE%20-%20The%20Work%20of%20Violence%20MARCH%202011%20TO%20SEND.doc The Work of Violence: Armed Attacks at the Kennedy Road Shack Settlement]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Kerry Chance, Rhodes University, March 2011</ref>
The ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'' newspaper described the attack on Kennedy Road as a "hatchet job"<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-10-11-kennedy-olive-branch-a-sham Kennedy olive branch a sham Kennedy olive branch a sham], Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 11 October 2009</ref> and reported that "Two weeks earlier, eThekwini regional chairperson John Mchunu, addressing the ANC's regional general council, had specifically condemned the ABM for trying to divide the tripartite alliance" and that an ANC source had confirmed there "was a battle for the hearts and minds of the people of Kennedy Road ... There is a political twist to this thing."<ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-10-03-ethnic-tension-boils-over Ethnic Tension Boils Over], Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 3 October 2009</ref> The ''Mercury'' newspaper later reported that "The chairperson of the ANC's biggest and most influential region in KwaZulu-Natal, John Mchunu, has been awarded tenders [in housing construction] worth at least R40-million by the eThekwini municipality.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/general/news/newsprint.php?art_id=vn20100312042526674C372809&sf= ANC chief's fat-cat deals] By Wendy Jasson da Costa, ''The Mercury'', 12 March 2010</ref> Abahlali baseMjondolo claims to have been at the "forefront of exposing local government corruption, especially in the allocation of housing."<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=86059 Slum dwellers’ body wants Langa to lead attack probe] WILSON JOHWA, Business Day, 2009/11/0</ref>
The KwaZulu-Natal Department of Safety and Security held meetings for stakeholders after the attack however these were condemned as unrepresentative by church leaders, AbM representatives and a survey by the ''Mail and Guardian Newspaper'' which described them as "a sham".<ref name="Kennedy olive branch a sham">[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-10-11-kennedy-olive-branch-a-sham Kennedy olive branch a sham] ''Mail & Guardian''</ref> AbM said that they were victims of a 'purge' and that they refused to sit side by side with their attackers and called for an independent investigation into the attacks<ref name="Kennedy olive branch a sham"/> that should "in the interests of justice and truth, carefully and fairly investigate the actions of everyone, including the local and provincial ANC, the police, the intelligence services, the prosecutors, the courts and our movement, its various sub-committees and our supporters."<ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/7168 The Kennedy 12 Go To Trial Today], AbM Press Statement</ref>
Following the attack AbM and the KRDC, democratically elected structures,<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/> were removed from the settlement<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/> and the provincial government replaced these structures with an unelected ANC affiliated Community Policing Forum.<ref name="sds.ukzn.ac.za"/>
The attacks garnered national and international condemnation with some people labelling the events a 'coup'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=82548|title=Academics condemn attack on settlement|publisher=BusinessDay}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200910080964.html|title=Democracy's Everyday Death – The Country's Quiet Coup|publisher=AllAfrica}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abahlali.org/node/5894|title=Statement in support of Abahlali baseMjondolo|publisher=Abahlali baseMjondolo}}</ref> Churches also issued statements of condemnation.<ref>[http://www.sacc.org.za/news09/kennedy.html South African Council of Churches Appalled by Violent Attacks Against Democracy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109045317/http://www.sacc.org.za/news09/kennedy.html |date=9 January 2010 }}</ref>
A number of well known intellectuals, including [[Noam Chomsky]], expressed concern about the attacks<ref>[http://info.interactivist.net/node/13160 Statement in support of Abahlali baseMjondolo]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, by Noam Chomsky et al,9 October 2009</ref> and [[Human Rights Watch]],<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=86059] Wilson Johwa, 'Slum dwellers’ body wants Langa to lead attack probe', Business Day, 5 November 2009</ref> the Centre for the Study of Democracy,<ref>[http://www.ngopulse.org/press-release/call-president-establish-commission-inquiry-violence-against-shackdwellers] Call for President to Establish a Commission of Inquiry into Violence Against Shackdwellers</ref> The Norwegian Centre for Human Rights<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jus.uio.no/smr/english/about/programmes/serp/news/2009/abahlali/Letter |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206143444/http://www.jus.uio.no/smr/english/about/programmes/serp/news/2009/abahlali/Letter |archivedate=6 February 2012 |df=dmy }} Letter to President Jacob Zuma from the Norwegian Centre for Human Rights</ref> and [[Amnesty International]]<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/afr53/011/2009/en/] Failure to conduct impartial investigation into Kennedy Road violence is leading to further human rights abuses, Amnesty International, 16 December 2009</ref> supported the call for an independent commission of inquiry into the attacks. The government ignored this call.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/>
The Centre on Housing Rights and Evictions in Geneva issued a statement that expressed "grave concern about reports of organised intimidation and threats to members of advocacy group, Abahlali baseMjondolo."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio786.co.za/index.php/news/3445-abahlali-stands-defended |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005094237/http://www.radio786.co.za/index.php/news/3445-abahlali-stands-defended |archivedate=5 October 2011 |df=dmy }} Radio 786, 1 May 2010, Abahlali Stands Defended</ref><ref>[http://www.cohre.org/view_page.php?page_id=424 South Africa: Attacks on housing rights activists must stop]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Centre on Housing Rights & Evictions, Geneva, 12 May 2010</ref>
Considerable concern was expressed about the legal process following the arrests of twelve people after the attacks.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/6104 Shack dwellers falsely arrested, says bishop], Kamini Padayachee, ''The Mercury'', 19 November 2009</ref><ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/6117 'Produce the evidence’, demands Bishop Rubin Phillip] Diakonia Council of Churches, 29 November 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.abahlali.org/node/6699 Justice delayed and denied for 12 Kennedy Road accused], Jeff Guy, ''The Mercury'', 13 May 2010</ref> [[Amnesty International]] has expressed concern<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/region/south-africa/report-2011 Amnesty International South Africa Report 2011]. Amnesty.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> and the New York-based [[Centre for Constitutional Rights]] sent an urgent appeal to the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Situation of Human Rights Defenders to ask her to investigate the case of the attack on Abahlali baseMjondolo and subsequent judicial process.<ref>[http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-appeals-un-behalf-of-south-african-shack-dwellers-movement CCR Appeals to UN on Behalf of South African Shack Dwellers Movement], 1 December 2010</ref>
On 18 July 2011, the case against the 12 accused members of Abahlali baseMjondolo collapsed.<ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/8142 Press statement by the Unemployed Peoples Movement], 18 July 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71619?oid=252931&sn=Detail&pid=71616 The ANC and the failing of democratic governance], Paul Trewhela, ''Politics Web'', 27 August 2011</ref> The Socio-Economic Rights Institute of South Africa issued a statement saying that the "charges were based on evidence which now appears almost certainly to have been manufactured" and that the Magistrate had described the state witnesses as "“belligerent”, “unreliable” and “dishonest”.<ref>[http://www.seri-sa.org/images/stories/seri_kennedy_12_press_release_18jul11.pdf "Kennedy 12" Acquitted]. (PDF) . Retrieved on 4 December 2011.</ref> Amnesty International noted that the court had found that "police had directed some witnesses to point out members of Abahlali-linked organisations at the identification parade".<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/region/south-africa/report-2012 Amnesty International Annual Report 2012]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|South Africa}}

===Other land and housing movements=== * The [[Bhumi Uchhed Pratirodh Committee]] in India * The [[EZLN]] in Mexico * [[Fanmi Lavalas]] in Haiti * The [[Homeless Workers' Movement]] in Brazil * The [[Landless Workers' Movement]] in Brazil * [[Movement for Justice in el Barrio]] in the United States of America * [[Narmada Bachao Andolan]] in India * [[Take Back the Land]] in the United States of America

===Films about Abahlali baseMjondolo=== * [http://www.behance.net/gallery/Abahlali-BaseMjondolo-Informative-animation/3474045 Amnesty International Film on Abahlali baseMjondolo] * [http://rajpatel.org/2011/07/18/dear-mandela/ Dear Mandela - feature length documentary] a multi-award-winning film *[http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/482/77583.html Dear Mandela wins big in Brooklyn], by Valencia Talane, ''Biz Community'', 28 June 2012 by Dara Kell & Christopher Nizza, 2011 [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117948369/ Dear Mandela], by Ronnie Schieb ''Variety'' * [http://www.vimeo.com/5971780 Txaboletan bizi direnak] by Elkartasun Bideak, 2009 (English dialogue with Basque subtitles) * [http://abahlali.org/node/5355 Amandla Awethu] by Elkartasun Bideak, 2009 * [http://www.abahlali.org/node/5183 From the Shacks to the Constitutional Court] by Dara Kell & Christopher Nizza, 2009 * [http://fahamubooks.org/book/?GCOI=90638100032170 A Place in the City] by Jenny Morgan, 2008 * [http://eng.habitants.org/zero_evictions_campaign/the_2008_world_zero_evictions_days_video_contest_you_have_until_31_12_08_to_vote!/dear_mandela Dear Mandela]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (advance trailer) by Dara Kell & Christopher Nizza, 2008 * [http://www.abahlali.org/node/2659 The Right to Know: The Fight for Open Democracy in South Africa] by Ben Cashdan, 2007 * [http://www.abahlali.org/node/239 Nayager Falls, Abahlali Rises] by Sally Gilles and Fazel Khan, 2007 * [http://abahlali.org/node/149 Breyani & the Councillor] by Sally Gilles and Fazel Khan, 2006 * [http://abahlali.org/node/611 Kennedy Road and the Councillor] by Aoibheann O'Sullivan, 2005

{{For|the winning song of the [[Sanremo Music Festival 1979]]|Mino Vergnaghi}} {{Infobox song | name = Amare | cover = Adrijana_-_Amare.jpeg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Adrijana Krasniqi|Adrijana]] | album = | released = 26 February 2017 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = 2016 | studio = | venue = | genre = {{Hlist|[[Hip hop music|Hip hop]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[electronic music|electronic]]}} | length = 2:50 | label = [[Universal Music Group|Universal Music Sweden]] | writer = {{hlist|[[Adrijana Krasniqi]]|Martin Tjärnberg}} | producer = | prev_title = Nån som mig | prev_year = 2017 | next_title = | next_year = }} "'''Amare'''" is a song recorded by Swedish rapper [[Adrijana Krasniqi|Adrijana]]. It took part in [[Melodifestivalen 2017]], and placed sixth in the first semi-final on 4 February 2017 and was written by Adrijana and Martin Tjärnberg.{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/02/04/melodifestivalen-ace-wilder-nano/|title=MELODIFESTIVALEN: ACE WILDER AND NANO TO STOCKHOLM|date=4 February 2017|publisher=Eurovoix|website=eurovoix.com|author=The NPBC}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/se/album/amare-single/id1200441831|title=Amare - Single|publisher=iTunes|accessdate=23 February 2017}} | title1 = Amare | length1 = 2:50 }} ==Chart performance== ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! revision.text:
The '''Anglo-Belgian Society''' is an organisation whose purpose is "to maintain and develop on a personal level the [[friendship]] which has always existed between the [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Belgium|Belgian]] people and to commemorate the brotherhood in arms which arose from their mutual loyalty to the treaty of 1839". It was founded in 1983, incorporating the '''Anglo-Belgian Union''' (A-BU) (founded 1918) and '''Cercle Royal Belge de Londres''' (founded 1922). Its members include Belgians living in Britain, and British people and companies with an interest in Belgium. {{As of| 2009}} it has nearly 500 members.
==External links== *[http://www.anglo-belgiansoc.com/ Anglo-Belgian Society website]
[[Category:Organizations established in 1983]] [[Category:Belgium–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:United Kingdom friendship associations]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Belgium]] [[Category:1983 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Belgium friendship associations]]
{{Belgium-stub}} {{UK-org-stub}}

{{Constitutions of Poland}} {{expand language|topic=|langcode=pl|otherarticle=Nowela sierpniowa|date=March 2015}} The '''August Novelization''' ({{lang-pl|Nowela sierpniowa}}) of 2 August 1926 was a set of [[constitutional amendment|amendment]]s to the 1921 [[March Constitution of Poland]].
These amendments were proposed and adopted by national [[plebiscite]] after [[Józef Piłsudski]] took power in the [[May Coup (Poland)|May Coup]].
There were four main clauses in the amendments.
* The [[President of Poland|President]] may dismiss the [[Sejm]] (parliament) and the [[Senate of Poland|Senate]]. * The President may issue acts (''rozporządzenia'') having statutory power with the approval of the Sejm. * The Sejm may not dissolve itself. * If the Sejm cannot agree on the state budget, the budget may be passed by the government.
== References == * {{cite book |title=Polskie konstytucje |last=Ajnenkiel |first=Andrzej |authorlink=Andrzej Ajnenkiel |coauthors= |year=1983 |publisher=Wiedza Powszechna |location=Warszawa |isbn=83-214-0256-9 |pages= |language=pl}}

[[File:Bern - Botanischer Garten Gebäude.jpg|thumb|right|The Bern Botanical Garden]] The '''Bern Botanical Garden''' ({{lang-de|Botanischer Garten Bern}}; BOGA) is a [[botanical garden]] located in [[Bern]], the capital city of [[Switzerland]].{{cite web | url = http://www.botanischergarten.ch/boga/home.html | title = Botanischer Garten Bern | language = German |trans-title=Botanical Garden of Bern | publisher = Botanischer Garten Bern | accessdate = 2014-10-10}} The garden is listed as a [[Swiss Inventory of Cultural Property of National and Regional Significance|cultural property of national significance]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bevoelkerungsschutz.admin.ch/internet/bs/de/home/themen/kgs/kgs_inventar/a-objekte.html |title=Kantonsliste A-Objekte |year=2014 |work=KGS Inventar |publisher=Federal Office of Civil Protection |language=German |accessdate=2014-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628110559/http://www.bevoelkerungsschutz.admin.ch/internet/bs/de/home/themen/kgs/kgs_inventar/a-objekte.html |archivedate=2010-06-28 |df= }} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{commonscat-inline|Botanischer Garten Bern|Bern Botanical Garden}} * [http://www.botanischergarten.ch/boga/home.html Web site of the garden]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Limeskastell |Name = Gerulata
''(Kastell Rusovce)'' |Antiker Name = ''Gerulata'', ''Gerulate'' |Bild = Gerulata.jpg |Bildbeschreibung = Gerulata |Limes= [[Limes Pannonicus|Upper Pannonia]] |Abschnitt= Section 2 |Belegung von bis = 1st to 4th century AD |Kastelltyp = Cohort and Ala fort,
square fort with rounded corners surrounded by a double ditch (''Spitzgraben''), ''Burgus'' of Late Antiquity |Truppenteil = a) ''legio XIV'' (?),
b) ''cohors V Callaecorum Lucensium'' (?),
c) ''ala I Canennefatum'',
d) ''equites Sagittarii'' |Abmessungen oder Fläche = a) wood and earth fort, width: 113 m
b) stone fort I, width: 133–166 m,
c) ''burgus'': 39 × 30 m |Verwendetes Material = a) wood and earth design
b) stone design |Kurzbeschreibung = Nothing visible above ground,
Foundation walls of the ''burgus'' were conserved and made accessible in a visitors' area |Heutiger Ortsname = [[Rusovce]] |Nebenbox = -- |Breitengrad = |Längengrad = |Region-ISO = SK-BL |Höhe = 130 |Im Limesverlauf vorher liegendes Kastell = {{Interlanguage link multi|Kleinkastell Stopfenreuth|de}} (northwest) |Im Limesverlauf nachfolgendes Kastell = {{Interlanguage link multi|Kastell Ad Flexum|de}} ([[Mosonmagyaróvár]]) (southeast) }} '''Gerulata''' was a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] [[military camp]] located near today's [[Rusovce]], a borough of [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]]. It was part of the [[Roman province]] of [[Pannonia]] and was built in the 2nd century as a part of the [[Limes Romanus|frontier defence]] system. It was abandoned in the 4th century, when Roman legions withdrew from [[Pannonia]]. Today there is a museum, which is part of the [[Bratislava City Museum]]. Archaeologists have unearthed its remnants and their discoveries are on exhibition in the hall of the museum, which is open in summer and can be near the Church of St Mary Magdalene in the town. Beyond the remains of the Roman forum, fragments of structures and gravestones, bronze, iron, ceramic and stone pieces are on show in a museum showing daily life. The best preserved object is a quadrilateral building 30 metres long and 30 metres wide, with 2.4 metre thick walls. ==References== * http://slovakianguide.com/en/bratislava-city-museum-ancient-gerulata-rusovce ==External links== * [http://www.slovenskehrady.sk/?show=object&which=Gerulata Gerulata] {{sk icon}} {{coord|48|03|22|N|17|08|59|E|display=title|region:SK-BL_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} [[Category:History of Bratislava]] [[Category:Roman frontiers]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Slovakia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bratislava]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Bratislava]] [[Category:Roman sites in Slovakia]] [[Category:Roman legionary fortresses in Slovakia]] {{AncientRome-stub}} {{Slovakia-struct-stub}} {{fort-stub}} {{Europe-archaeology-stub}}

revision.text:
The International Centre for Migration, Health and Development (ICMHD) is a Swiss-based non-profit organization based in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. It is a research, training and policy centre founded in 1995 with the purpose of improving, protecting and advocating for the health and welfare of people on the move. ICMHD is a [[WHO]] Collaborating Centre for Health-Related Issues Among People Displaced by Disasters and a [[UNFPA]] Implementing Partner. It also works with other UN agencies as well as with universities and research and training institutions throughout the world. ICMHD’s mandate is to provide governments, UN agencies, NGOs and other parties with information and technical support on how the movement of people affects, and is affected by health and social conditions, and how this dynamic can be best managed to the benefit of everyone concerned. The work of ICMHD is predicated on the fact that the right to health must apply to all people, including migrants, refugees and others who find themselves on the move for political, environmental, social and economic reasons. ICMHD believes that in protecting the health and welfare of people on the move, the public health and security of the larger society is also strengthened. The work of ICMHD covers all types of population movement, including economically motivated migration (documented and undocumented), forced migration (environmental and political), nomadic migration, and the movement of uniformed service groups such as peacekeepers and military personnel. From the perspective of health, health care and health systems, ICMHD addresses non-communicable, communicable and parasitic diseases. ICMHD is currently working on research, training and policy options in the areas of HIV/AIDS, TB, viral hepatitis, diabetes, malaria, reproductive health and psycho-social impacts of uprooting. It is also addressing the question of health care worker migration and alternative approaches to preventing excess brain drain from developing countries.
The Executive Committee is composed of Dr. Eamon Kelly (president), Dr Mohamed-Lardi Abdelmoumene (vice-president), Professor [[Monique Bégin]] (treasurer), and [[Manuel Carballo (Epidemiologist)|Dr. Manuel Carballo]] (executive director). ==Office Locations== [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]
[[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]
[[Rome]], [[Italy]]
[[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia]] == External links == *[http://www.icmhd.wordpress.com ICMHD's Blog] *[http://www.icmhd.ch ICMHD's Website] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in Switzerland]] [[Category:International organisations based in Switzerland]] [[Category:World Health Organization]] [[Category:Human migration]]

'''Kastrup Glasværk''' was a Danish glasworks located in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Kastrup Glasværk was also the parent company of Hellerup Glasværk, De forenede Glasværker in [[Odense]] and Aarhus Glasværk in [[Aarhus]].
==History== Kastrup Glasværk was founded on 12 October 1847 by Christian Conrad Sophus Danneskiold-Samsøe. He has inherited [[Holmegård]] glasworks at [[Næstved]] after his mother in 1943. The company was converted into an [[aktieselskab]] in 1873. In 1881, the company acquired Tuborg Fabrikers Glasværk whouse name was subsequently changed to Hellerup Glasværk. In 1883, the company also took over Godthaab Glasværk in [[Helsingør]]. In 1907, Kastrup Glasværk acquired A/S De forenede Glasværker in [[Odense]] and Frederiksberg Glasværk. A/S De forenede Glasværker comprised Fyns Glasværk in Odense (founded on 11 June 1874) and Aarhus Glasværk in [[Aarhus]] (founded 1898). In 1918, Aalborg Glasværk in [[Aalborg]] (founded in 1853) was acquired.
In 1865, Kastrup Glasværk merged with Holmegaard under the nameKastrup og Holmegaards Glasværker A/S. The principal shareholders were [[Carlsberg Group]], [[De forende Bryggerier]] and Elisabeth Lassen who had inherited Holmegaard after her father (count Aage Danneskiold-Samsøe( in 1945. The merged company had about 1,935 employeesThe and a total production of about 102,000 tonnes. The production ceased in 1879.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardernet.dk/Glasswork/Kastrup_Glasvaerk_1847-1979.htm|title=KKastrup Glasværk, 1847-1879|language=Danish|website=hardernet.dk|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==Headquarters== Kastrup Glasværk was from 1892 headquartered at [[Nørre Voldgade]] 12 in central Copenhagen. The Historicist building was designed by the architect [[Philip Smidth]]. The company name is still seen on the facade. The building is now home to Teknisk Landsforbund.
==Products== Kastrup Glasværk was initially a manufacturer of bottles. The production was automatized in 1912. The company later also began to manufacture other products such as drinking glass, tableware, flasks, bell jars and light fictures.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Defunct glassmaking companies]] [[Category:Glassmaking companies of Denmark]] [[Category:Danish companies established in 1847]]
{{Denmark-stub}}
